primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The movement from the bondage of Pharaoh's system of scarcity and anxiety to a life of freedom and justice governed by the God of Sinai and Jesus.

tekstueel_bewijs: we move our lives into a new zone of reality
we must practice in order to break addictive habits
new life of freedom and justice
The God of the commandments is the God of Exodus deliverance
the news that God gives in Jesus

ontvanger.identificatie: The Hearer and the Disadvantaged Neighbor
tekstueel_bewijs: recognize the legitimacy... of every neighbor

helper.identificatie: The Ten Commandments / Lenten Disciplines / Jesus' Example
tekstueel_bewijs: The Ten Commandments are rules by which to celebrate and maintain
Lenten discipline is... about embracing new disciplines
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Sender/Helper who provides the 'strategies', but the Hearer is the Subject who must 'stay' emancipated.
helper.rol_van_geest: Absent; focus is on the 'work of Lent' as human intentionality.

tegenstander.identificatie: Pharaoh / The System of Scarcity / The Status Quo
tekstueel_bewijs: Pharaoh... a brutal concentration of power and wealth
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Pharaoh is a 'freighted word' for economic and social systems of exploitation rather than an ontological power like Sin or Death.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God's historical deliverance of Israel from Egypt.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: God
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The primary program (Hearer staying free) is dependent on the memory of the secondary program (God's past act), but the sermon focuses on the Hearer's maintenance of that state.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God... brought you out of the land of Egypt

voorbeelden: this is what you must do
the work of Lent consists in...
God's power for new life (mentioned as something the Empire could not receive)

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon assumes the Hearer has the 'Savoir' (knowledge of the system) and focuses heavily on 'Devoir' (the obligation to practice disciplines) to maintain freedom.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Pharaoh) to ~S2 (Resistance) to S1 (Emancipation), with a constant warning of falling back into ~S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in 'intentionality and discipline'—the human work of Lent.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: S2 is treated as a systemic/psychological habit rather than a terminal condition requiring a Savior.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon uses strong biblical imagery of God as Deliverer, the 'engine' is moralistic/synergistic: God delivered in the past, but the Hearer must now use 'strategies' to stay free.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: if you want to remain free from Pharaoh, this is what you must do.
The work of Lent consists in three Lenten acts.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Jesus is presented as the ultimate performer of the strategies.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Jesus did not just 'perform' strategies; He is the Emancipation itself who holds the believer when they fail the strategies.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Pressure to perform; anxiety about 'falling back' into the rat-race.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Sanctification is viewed as a work of human discipline (staying free) rather than a fruit of the Spirit.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'indicative' of Exodus to the 'imperative' of the Commandments is logically clear but theologically weighted toward the imperative.
spanning_punten: The cross is called a 'sign of a new way of life' rather than an objective substitutionary act.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The cross is... a sign of a new way of life that departs from the way of Pharaoh.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon relies on human 'intentionality' rather than the Spirit's 'Pouvoir'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is described as an 'addictive habit' or 'rat-race'—a systemic trap rather than total depravity.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon correctly identifies God as the historical Sender but incorrectly positions the Hearer as the primary Subject responsible for maintaining the Object (Freedom).

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The Hearer is the subject of 'staying emancipated'.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Christ as the Subject who keeps us free.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'strategies for staying free,' use 'How Christ holds us fast when Pharaoh calls.'

identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the sheep who is kept by the Shepherd.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the 'new governance' is God's active rule, not just our 'intentionality'.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how the 'Easter body' of Jesus actually empowers the believer, rather than just 'inviting' them.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Sin as a power we cannot break by 'discipline' alone.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: If the opponent is just a 'habit,' we don't need a Savior, just a coach.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: God's ongoing deliverance (Program 1) must be the ground for every Lenten act (Program 2).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon has a powerful social critique but risks turning the Gospel into a new Law of 'intentionality'. Re-centering Christ as the active Subject of the present tense will transform this from a lecture on discipline into a sermon of grace.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, the sermon is brilliant and evocative; semiotically, it is anthropocentric.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis correctly identifies the Exodus context, but the actantial shift makes the 'Big Ten' a burden rather than a gift.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that despite the 'Jesus' language, the 'Subject' of the verbs is almost exclusively 'We'.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'addiction' metaphor which inherently places the burden of 'recovery' on the Subject's willpower.
